title: Where do we draw the line?
body:
Ever played a game with a person who totally freaked out about stealing on cs or one kill?

Then that person plays in a way that is passive aggressive? 

They might say something like, "Looks like you need the gold." 

or, "Take my creeps, you can use the cs." 

As a result of an honest mistake in an attempt to help a fellow teammate, you get punished by a passive aggressive player who doesn't group for fights, and play counter productive to winning. 

Has this happened to you in a game? 

How do we deal with these players who don't say anything wrong, but we know they are trying to lose, but it is not obvious, so they don't get seen on the Riot radar? 

We always see blatant chat restrictions and perma bans for overt a hole stuff here on the forums, but what about those not so obvious people who have been skirting the limits of the rules, getting by and ruining so many more games? 

What do we do about these guys? 
I think this is the worst of all the problems here, because they do this non-stop, and unchecked. 
They usually will do this to teach someone a lesson and cause someone else to tilt or flame people on the team, resulting in another player losing it and getting banned. This kind of manipulation is despicable and you are the people in my opinion that do not deserve to play the game, because of the ceaseless damage to do to the community.

replies.body:
>How do we deal with these players who don't say anything wrong, but we know they are trying to lose, but it is not obvious, so they don't get seen on the Riot radar?

Realistically? You can't.

Riot decides whom is breaking the rules and deserves a punishment, not any one individual player.

This concept of someone being malicious while carefully staying under the radar is not a foreign concept anywhere, be it a game or real life. This is not a problem that really gets solved, because part of the problem is the person actively making sure that they're following the letter of the rules.

You can't solve that.

Well that sucks. 

When you get this in your games how do you handle it or deal with it?

> [{quoted}](name=CominTowardsYa,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=6PX2khE2,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2019-11-04T08:30:46.970+0000)
>
> Well that sucks. 
> 
> When you get this in your games how do you handle it or deal with it?

It's their match too. So they're really just shooting themselves in the foot if they make a habit of throwing game because of petty reasons. Whereas I can treat the loss due to something outside of my control, they can only pretend the same.

To put it simply, I treat it like I lost a dice roll. Is it frustrating if the dice doesn't land where you want? Sure. But getting angry at the dice isn't going to change what number they landed on. Sometimes you'll run into jerks, it's unavoidable. I report them, mute if necessary, and move on. The best I can do is hope they trip up and Riot does detect it.

Sounds like good advice for anyone to follow in general. 

I agree with the dice roll analogy, makes sense. 

I have gotten a lot better at not being that guy, and not exacerbating it when it happens in a game.
Your wording is pointed in one direction, to burn these players. Have you considered that maybe you're wrong to some extent?

Sure I have considered that, but am I going to do the work and look at my own wrongs and biases, or are you saying you'd like to try it out and see how it goes. 

How am I wrong?

I'm a little confused by the first sentence. I play as best I can even when tilted. As such I often switch to ultra-passive farming and let my allies know that will be my prerogative, when playing from behind- especially when tilted. Which is unfortunately not to the liking of an aggressive ally, sometimes, which triggers situations like what you're saying and the best I can do is soldier on trying to not get killed and keeping my mouth shut. 

I believe that you're pushing the issue as the worst of all issues, firstly. Recognize that it's only a problem for you, and while it might be a common problem, it is not your place to demand action. "Unchecked", "manipulation", "ceaseless damage", you're pressing too hard.

Second, in line with what I said above, consider these people as humans who are experiencing an emotion that is affecting them. People get angry. Anger passes, if the beholder allows it. Many people need help doing that. Leaving lane, while a logical choice, didn't help in that regard, and he eventually left. And he'll pay the price for that, which might be nothing if it's not a recurring choice of his.

Lastly, that poll. It might as well be a Y/N "Agree with me you shitheads!".

I don't think the poll reflects that, there are other options. 

Yeah, it isn't the worst issue, but I see it more in my games, than overt flaming.

1) Yes, _something must be done_   (insert evil laughter)
2) Yes, I ignore it    ("you're right but don't care/nothing can be done")
5) repeat of 2) with a tint of 4)

those are okay

3) Yes, I like them    ("yes and I encourage under-the-rader griefing!")
4) No, never, I'm probably lying    (but of course this happens so often we all must be experiencing it! __sarcasm__)
6) I am this person   ("of course I will expose my under-the-radar behavior to justify it to you")

those are not

Okay I see your perspective. I can't go back and change it though, so if you want to vote, you'll just have to use the one that best represents your situation. Also remember that, 4) No never, I'm probably lying, isn't _that_ bad considering the likelihood of something never occurring is rare. 

Why did you insert the evil laughter though? I wonder what you think of when you insert the evil laughter.
You'll just have to figure that out on your own, _muhahahaha_

Controversial opinion incoming: People are allowed to have bad games, and a lot of what happens in a match is interpretive. To an extent I'd say players should be allowed to not try to win a match. Where I'd draw the line is pretty far in - Don't actually intentionally feed and don't leave the match. However, if a player is in chat expressing a negative attitude, I would say that is definitely crossing the line. For example, if they're an adc and they're afk-farming while your team is getting pushed in and steamrolled mid, I would say this is okay, and there's some viable reasoning to it if they're playing an especially farm-dependent adc like Twitch or Vayne. However, if they then say something in chat along the lines of "get away from me. I don't want anything to do with this team. Jungle difference. I'd carry you, but you're just not worth it," then there's an argument to be made that they're throwing the match.

I understand that. So you would draw the line only for blatant things? 
Well I think where you would draw the line and where Riot draws the line is in the same place, but I think the examples in my OP are pretty damn annoying. 

I have said I wouldn't carry a team, but never typed it in the chat, but my teammates insulted the hell out of me for honest mistakes. I hate that.
Yes, it is an unfixable problem. Humans are cunning and will always find a way to skirt the rules regardless of who is in charge.
